title: Estimated time to sync creeps up
body:
### Description

Started a fresh sync more than 24 hrs ago.  Here are some of the logs on the way:
```
-- Logs begin at Mon 2022-09-19 07:20:21 CEST, end at Tue 2022-09-20 13:22:08 CEST. --
```

### Has this worked before in a previous version?

Prysm has _never_ worked for me.

## ðŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction

Ditto

## ðŸ”¥ Error

Sync time just keeps creeping up.  Currently at 60+ hrs.


## ðŸŒ  Your Environment

**Operating System:**

```
Ubuntu 18.04 LTS
```

**What version of Prysm are you running? (Which release)**

v3.1.1

**Anything else relevant (validator index / public key)?**

The exec layer client is geth v1.10.25: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/releases/tag/v1.10.25
..i.e. that version that waits for beacon chain to dl before dl:ing its own stuff (in order to avoid state snapshot spam..?  see release those release notes).   Geth says this:
```
syys 20 12:56:16 sampsa-asus geth[15754]: WARN [09-20|12:56:16.345] Beacon client online, but never received consensus updates. Please ensure your beacon client is operational to follow the chain!
syys 20 13:01:16 sampsa-asus geth[15754]: WARN [09-20|13:01:16.376] Beacon client online, but never received consensus updates. Please ensure your beacon client is operational to follow the chain!
syys 20 13:06:16 sampsa-asus geth[15754]: WARN [09-20|13:06:16.406] Beacon client online, but never received consensus updates. Please ensure your beacon client is operational to follow the chain!
syys 20 13:11:16 sampsa-asus geth[15754]: WARN [09-20|13:11:16.440] Beacon client online, but never received consensus updates. Please ensure your beacon client is operational to follow the chain!
...
```

appendum: running as systemd daemon.  Here you can see the actual command used to run it:
```
prysm.service - Prysm consensus layer client
   Loaded: loaded (/home/sampsa/.config/systemd/user/prysm.service; enabled; vendor preset: enabled)
   Active: active (running) since Mon 2022-09-19 11:50:31 CEST; 1 day 1h ago
```

Are you running two beacon nodes?

PID 1296 was at 4259808/4728644, very close to the head of the chain. 
And then it seems like you have a second process with PID 15521 that is much farther behind 1920192/4737418.

In any case, I understand the frustration caused by this time remaining estimate. Phase 0 syncs at about 100 blocks per second while Altair or Bellatrix syncs about 10 blocks per second. So the estimated time remaining seems to stay about the same or go up as progress slows. The beacon chain can take 3 to 4 days to sync from genesis.

Similar scenarios in my node as well. I have 2 geth archival nodes connected to 2 beacon nodes and both seems to have completed merge. But the nodes seems to be syncing very slowly. PFB the status from both nodes

GETH
node 0 - INFO [09-21|06:25:06.231] Imported new potential chain segment blocks=1 txs=295 mgas=22.221 elapsed=9.974s mgasps=2.228 number=15,559,291 hash=0961a7..1d9571 age=2d21h47m dirty=0.00B
node 1 - INFO [09-21|06:25:07.196] Imported new potential chain segment blocks=1 txs=371 mgas=27.281 elapsed=9.188s mgasps=2.969 number=15,557,806 hash=9b6067..887a31 age=3d2h46m dirty=0.00B

BEACON
node 0 - time="2022-09-21 06:26:27" level=info msg="Processing block batch of size 64 starting from 0xb47a08d1... 4722176/4743130 - estimated time remaining 15m39s" blocksPerSecond=22.3 peers=49 prefix=initial-sync
node 1 - time="2022-09-21 06:25:20" level=info msg="Processing block batch of size 64 starting from 0x2ff82104... 4720690/4743124 - estimated time remaining 29m19s" blocksPerSecond=12.8 peers=45 prefix=initial-sync

The slots(3 days behind current slot) in beacon seems to be in sync with the block shown in geth node. Can anyone confirm if this is healthy and our sync is well and good but a bit slow ?

Sorry about the confusion.. It seems I mixed up two different logs: the earlier PID 1296 corresponds to an earlier desperate attempt to run prysm & geth (an older version which I updated) together.  I've cross-checked: there is only one prysm running.

So let's concentrate on that later run (pls dont mind the pid this time: I stopper & restarted the daemon):

The problem here seems to be that blocks per second is 9.6?

What is the speed of creating new blocks in the beacon chain?  12 bps? (bps=as in blocks per second)

Then I will never catch up, of course.  Why the bps is so slow?

My internet connection is 300mbps (as in megabits per second)

My laptop has ealier ran at least geth without no problems (a slightly older 8-core penguing with SSD).

The number of peers is quite high.  Could it be a problem?

> The problem here seems to be that blocks per second is 9.6?
> 
> What is the speed of creating new blocks in the beacon chain? 12 bps? (bps=as in blocks per second)
> 
> Then I will never catch up, of course. Why the bps is so slow?

A block is produced every 12 seconds. You are syncing at 9 blocks per second, so you will eventually catch up. The bottleneck is likely disk I/O and CPU or memory constraints. That internet connection is sufficient and it seems like you have plenty of peers.

Running multiple instances of beacon chain and geth on the same machine will slow each of them down since they are sharing resources. For Prysm, you could consider using checkpoint sync with a trusted endpoint. https://docs.prylabs.network/docs/prysm-usage/checkpoint-sync

Well, I am _not_ running multiple instances of geth & prysm.  Just one instance of geth (that's at the moment just sitting there, waiting for prysm to sync) and one instance of prysm.

You pointed out that beacon chain produces 0.08 blocks per second.  My client's speed is 9 blocks per second.

What would be an acceptable blocks-per-second speed to sync from scratch within a few days (it's too late & I'm too lazy to do the math, so I just ask for a number instead :) ) .. what is the typical blocks per second _you_ are running in your lab?

> Well, I am not running multiple instances of geth & prysm. Just one instance of geth (that's at the moment just sitting there, waiting for prysm to sync) and one instance of prysm.

OK, I was confused why you had two processes originally. One of them was almost entirely synced and the other was about half way. 

> What would be an acceptable blocks-per-second speed to sync from scratch within a few days (it's too late & I'm too lazy to do the math, so I just ask for a number instead :) ) .. what is the typical blocks per second you are running in your lab?

Your results here are typical. The initial sync process is slower in the later phases of the beacon chain. 

Closing this issue now as there doesn't seem to be any technical issues. We are aware that sync slows down over time.
